text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 4.23.22.1.1. Renamed “Background” and updated content.

IRM 4.23.22.5. Added information on cases designated for litigation and a cross-reference to IRM 33.3.6, Other Legal Advice; Designating a Case for Litigation, and IGM NHQ-04-0820-0003, Interim Guidance on Designation of Cases for Litigation.
4.23.22.8.6(4). Added “Reminder” that examiners and group managers should ensure and documents related to all the issues are uploaded to IMS.
IRM 4.23.22.11.1(3). Added “Reminder” that Form 886-A should not be enclosed with Letter
IRM 4.23.22.11.8(1).Reference changed to reﬂect the consolidation of the Bankruptcy Handbook to new IRM 4.27.1, Bankruptcy - Examiner Responsibilities and Procedures.
4.23.22.11.16(2). Added Enrolled Retirement Plan Agents to list of representatives.
Editorial, typographical, and technical changes have been made throughout this
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 4.23.10, dated May 21, 2018. Information on Interim Guidance Memorandum NHQ-04-0820-0003, Interim Guidance on Designation of Cases for Litigation, issued August 24, 2020, is incorporated into this IRM.

Provides Servicewide instructions for employees of all operating divisions involved with the correct ﬁling, reporting, and payment of employ- ment taxes. IRM 4.23 serves as the founda- tion for consistent administration of em- ployment taxes by various IRS operating divisions. IRM 4.10.8 Examination of This section includes Returns, Report guidelines for the Writing preparation of audit ﬁndings, in terms of content and format; it also provides instruc- tions for some case closing requirements. ) Employment tax examiners should consider the disclosure provisions when preparing agreed and unagreed case reports. See the Privacy, Liaison and Disclosure web site at: Home.aspx for additional information. (

) Taxpayers are entitled to a fair and impartial administrative appeal of most decisions, including many penalties. If agreement cannot be reached on the proposed adjustments, examiners should explain the procedure for istrative appeal as well as the option to pay any deﬁciency and ﬁle a claim refund if the taxpayer or taxpayer’s representative is not familiar with these procedures. ) The Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS) offers Examination personnel a to resolve audit issues utilizing the settlement authority and mediation skills of Appeals while retaining jurisdiction of the case. FTS is designed to be completed within
days (for LB&I taxpayers) or

days (for SB/SE taxpayers). LB&I (or SB/SE), the taxpayer, and Appeals are active participants in the process, and all three parties must agree before a proposed resolution can be implemented. , Your Appeal Rights and How to Prepare a Protest If You Don’t Agree. Generally, if the taxpayer submits new information or evidence to Appeals, raises a new issue Examination has not considered, the case will be returned to Examination. See IRM
, Returning a Case to Examination – ATE, and IRM
, Cases Returned from Appeals. The following is a list of cases that are excluded from Appeals consideration: a. Fewer than
days remain on the statute of limitations when the case is received in Appeals. b. Request/claim for abatement of unpaid tax that is not an audit reconsid- eration. See IRM

, Claims for Abatement, Audit and Supplemental Reports, (taxpayer has no judicial rights). c. Taxpayer disagrees solely on moral, religious, political, constitutional, conscientious, or similar grounds. See IRM
, No Appeals ence or Concession on Certain Arguments. d. Cases designated for litigation. See IRM
, Other Legal Advice; Designating a Case for Litigation, and IGM NHQ-

, Returning Case to Examination – ATE. See IRM

IRC 7436(a) provides the Tax Court review rights concerning certain employ- ment tax determinations. IRC 7436 only applies to employment tax cases in which the IRS determines that at least one worker should be reclassiﬁed as employee and/or that the taxpayer is not entitled to relief under section 530 of the Revenue Act of 1978. The law requires that any employment tax that depends upon such determinations cannot be assessed unless the taxpayer has been given an opportunity to ﬁle a petition for Tax Court review of the Service’s determinations on one or both of those two issues.
Note: Only one of the issues must be present for the Tax Court to have jurisdiction.
